Intuition: Use HashMap to store complement (target - num). Check if current num exists as key in O(1).
Sort array first. Fix one element and use two pointers for remaining two. Skip duplicates to avoid repeat triplets.
Two pointers at ends. Area = min(height) × width. Move the shorter pointer inward hoping for taller line.
Two passes: left-to-right for prefix products and right-to-left for suffix products. Multiply both for result.
Kadane's Algorithm: Track current sum and reset to 0 if negative. Keep global max. DP: dp[i] = max(nums[i], dp[i-1] + nums[i]).
Track both max and min at each position (negative × negative = positive). Result is max of all maxProducts.
Prefix sum + HashMap. Store count of each prefix sum. If (currentSum - k) exists in map, add its count to result.
Find rightmost ascending pair (i, i+1). Swap nums[i] with smallest larger element on right. Reverse suffix after i.
Dutch National Flag: Three pointers (low, mid, high). 0s go left, 2s go right, 1s stay middle. One pass O(n).
Use HashSet for O(1) lookup. Only start counting from sequence start (num-1 not in set). Expand rightward.
Maintain 4 boundaries (top, bottom, left, right). Traverse right→down→left→up. Shrink boundaries after each direction.
Three reverses: reverse entire array, reverse first k elements, reverse remaining. Or use extra array with (i+k)%n indexing.
Use array indices as hash. Mark visited by negating nums[abs(num)-1]. If already negative, it's a duplicate.
Expand around center for each position. Check both odd (single center) and even (double center) palindromes.
Use sorted string as key in HashMap. All anagrams sort to same string. Group values by key.
Encode: length + delimiter + string (e.g., '4#word'). Decode: read length, skip delimiter, extract string.
Compare character by character across all strings. Stop at first mismatch or shortest string length.
Two pointers from ends. Skip non-alphanumeric. Compare lowercase characters. Meet in middle = valid.

Problem Name: Minimum Remove to Make Valid Parentheses
Intuition: Track indices of unmatched '(' in stack. Mark unmatched ')' for removal. Build result skipping invalid indices.
Expand around center for each position. Count both odd and even length palindromes. Sum all counts.
Greedy: Use value-symbol pairs in descending order. Subtract largest possible value repeatedly, append symbols.
Grade school multiplication. Position i*j contributes to result[i+j] and result[i+j+1]. Handle carries at end.
Expand right pointer. When duplicate found, shrink left until valid. Use HashSet or HashMap for O(1) char lookup.
Expand right until all chars covered. Contract left while maintaining validity. Track minimum window.

Problem Name: Find All Anagrams in a String
Intuition: Fixed-size sliding window = p.length. Compare frequency maps or use matches counter when frequencies align.
Window valid if length - maxFreq <= k. Track max frequency char count. Shrink left when invalid.
Monotonic decreasing deque. Remove smaller elements from back. Remove out-of-window elements from front. Front is max.
Fixed window of s1.length. Compare frequency arrays. Return true when frequencies match exactly.
Two pointers + track leftMax and rightMax. Water at position = min(leftMax, rightMax) - height. Move smaller pointer.
Two pointers from ends. On mismatch, try skipping left OR right char. Check if either remaining substring is palindrome.
Two pointers: slow for next non-zero position, fast for scanning. Swap when fast finds non-zero.
Record last occurrence of each char. Extend partition end to max last occurrence. Cut when index reaches end.
Compare character frequency counts. Use array[26] for lowercase or HashMap for unicode. Counts must match.
Count frequencies with HashMap. Use min-heap of size k, or bucket sort by frequency for O(n) solution.
Two passes: first count frequencies, second find first char with count 1. Return its index.
BFS with queue. Process level by level using queue size. Add all nodes at current level to result list.
Recursive: If node is p or q, return it. Get left and right results. If both non-null, current node is LCA.
Pass valid range (min, max) down. Left child: max = parent. Right child: min = parent. Or use inorder traversal.
BFS: Take last node of each level. Or DFS: Visit right first, take first node at each new depth.
Preorder traversal with null markers. Serialize to string. Deserialize by reading values and reconstructing recursively.
Recursive: Swap left and right children. Recursively invert both subtrees. Return root.
Recursive: return 1 + max(depth(left), depth(right)). Base case: null node returns 0.
Recursive: Both null = true. One null = false. Values equal AND left subtrees same AND right subtrees same.
Prefix sum technique. Track running sum. If (currentSum - target) in HashMap, add its count. Backtrack after recursion.

Problem Name: Construct Binary Tree from Preorder and Inorder
Intuition: Preorder first = root. Find root in inorder to split left/right subtrees. Recursively build with correct ranges.
Inorder traversal gives sorted order. Return kth element. Can use iterative with stack for early termination.
DFS/BFS from each unvisited land cell. Sink the island (mark as visited). Count number of DFS/BFS calls.
DFS with HashMap (original → clone). Create clone, store in map BEFORE recursing to handle cycles.
Multi-source BFS from all rotten oranges. Process level by level (minutes). Return -1 if fresh oranges remain.
DFS backtracking from each cell. Mark visited, explore 4 directions, unmark on backtrack. Match character by character.
Reverse DFS from ocean edges going uphill. Find intersection of cells reachable from both oceans.
Push opening brackets. Pop and match for closing brackets. Stack empty at end = valid.
Two stacks: main stack + min stack. Push current min to min stack. Pop from both. Peek min stack for getMin.
Monotonic decreasing stack of indices. Pop smaller temps and calculate days difference. Push current index.
Two stacks: one for counts, one for strings. Push on '[', pop and repeat on ']'. Build result iteratively.
Stack for numbers. Track last operator. For +/-, push number. For */, pop and compute immediately. Sum stack.
Stack of operands. Push numbers. On operator, pop two, compute, push result. Final stack top is answer.
Sort by start time. If current overlaps with last merged, extend end. Otherwise, add new interval.
Min-heap of end times. For each meeting: if start >= heap top, pop (reuse room). Push new end time. Heap size = rooms.
Add all intervals ending before newInterval. Merge overlapping intervals. Add remaining intervals.
Sort by end time (greedy). Keep interval with earliest end. Count removals when overlap detected.
Fibonacci: dp[i] = dp[i-1] + dp[i-2]. Can reach step i from i-1 or i-2. Space optimize to two variables.
dp[i] = max(dp[i-1], dp[i-2] + nums[i]). Either skip current house or rob it + best from two houses back.
Circular: houses 0 and n-1 are adjacent. Run House Robber I twice: skip first house OR skip last house. Take max.
dp[amount] = min coins needed. dp[i] = min(dp[i], dp[i-coin] + 1) for each coin. Bottom-up from 0 to amount.
dp[i][j] = dp[i-1][j] + dp[i][j-1]. Can only come from top or left. Base: first row and column = 1.
O(n²): dp[i] = max(dp[j] + 1) for all j < i where nums[j] < nums[i]. O(n log n): Binary search on tails array.
dp[i] = can segment s[0:i]. dp[i] = true if dp[j] is true AND s[j:i] is in dictionary for some j < i.
dp[i] = ways to decode s[0:i]. Add dp[i-1] if valid single digit. Add dp[i-2] if valid two-digit (10-26).
Greedy: Track maxReach. Update maxReach = max(maxReach, i + nums[i]). If maxReach >= last index, return true.
Iterative: Track prev, curr, next. Point curr.next to prev. Move pointers forward. Return prev.
Compare heads, attach smaller to result. Advance that pointer. Attach remaining list at end.
Floyd's: Slow moves 1 step, fast moves 2. If they meet, cycle exists. If fast reaches null, no cycle.
Two pointers with n-node gap. Move both until fast reaches end. Slow.next is the node to remove.
Find middle, reverse second half, merge alternating. Use slow/fast pointers to find middle.
HashMap + Doubly Linked List. Map for O(1) lookup. DLL for O(1) insert/remove. Move accessed nodes to head.
left = 0, right = n-1. mid = (left + right) / 2. Compare and halve search space. Return mid or -1.
Find which half is sorted. Check if target is in sorted half. Adjust left/right accordingly.

Problem Name: Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array
Intuition: Binary search: If mid > right, min is in right half. Otherwise min is in left half (including mid).
Treat 2D as 1D array. Binary search with index conversion: row = mid / cols, col = mid % cols.
Binary search: If nums[mid] < nums[mid+1], peak is on right. Otherwise peak is on left (including mid).
Use first row/column as markers. Track if first row/col originally had zeros. Mark then fill zeros.
Transpose matrix (swap [i][j] with [j][i]). Then reverse each row. Or rotate layer by layer from outside in.
Min-heap of size k. Push elements, pop if size > k. Top of heap is kth largest. Or use QuickSelect for O(n) avg.
Max-heap of size k by distance. Push points, pop if size > k. Heap contains k closest points.
Min-heap of list heads. Pop smallest, push its next node. Build result list. O(n log k) time.
For each element: include or exclude. Recursively build subsets. Add current subset at each step (including empty).
Swap current element with each remaining. Recurse. Backtrack by swapping back. Base: all elements placed.
Track open and close counts. Add '(' if open < n. Add ')' if close < open. Base: length = 2n.
Sort candidates. For each candidate, include (allowing repeats) or skip. Prune when sum exceeds target.
Map digits to letters. For each digit, try all its letters. Recurse to next digit. Collect at end.
HashMap (val → index) + Array. Insert: add to array and map. Delete: swap with last, update map, pop. Random: random array index.
Queue of timestamps. On hit: add timestamp. On getHits: remove timestamps older than 300s, return queue size.
Two stacks: back history and forward history. Visit clears forward. Back/forward moves between stacks.
Stack of reverse iterators. hasNext: flatten until top is integer. next: pop and return integer.
HashMap of key → sorted list of (timestamp, value). Binary search for largest timestamp <= query.
DFS with depth parameter. For integers: add value × depth. For lists: recurse with depth + 1.
Track min and max possible open count. '*' can be '(', ')', or empty. Valid if 0 is in [min, max] range at end.
Two binary searches: one for leftmost target, one for rightmost. Use left-biased and right-biased conditions.
Cycle detection in directed graph. Use 3-state DFS (unvisited, visiting, visited). Cycle = cannot finish.
Topological sort. DFS post-order + reverse, or BFS with in-degree (Kahn's algorithm). Return order or [] if cycle.
Tree = no cycles + fully connected. Check edges = n-1. DFS with parent tracking to detect cycles in undirected graph.
DFS/BFS from each unvisited node. Each new DFS start = new component. Count total components.
Union-Find: emails are nodes, union emails within same account. Group by root parent. Sort and format output.
Union-Find: process edges. If union returns false (already connected), that edge creates cycle. Return it.
Build graph from word order comparisons. Topological sort gives character order. Handle invalid cases.
Dijkstra's algorithm from source node. Track shortest time to each node. Return max time or -1 if unreachable.
Bellman-Ford with k+1 iterations. Or BFS/DFS with pruning. Track minimum cost to reach each node within stops limit.
Binary search on effort + BFS/DFS to check feasibility. Or Dijkstra treating max diff as edge weight.
BFS from top-left. 8-directional movement. First to reach bottom-right gives shortest path length.
Binary search on time + BFS/DFS to check reachability. Or Dijkstra with max elevation as edge weight.

Problem Name: Find the City With Smallest Number of Neighbors
Intuition: Floyd-Warshall for all pairs shortest paths. Count reachable cities within threshold for each city.

Problem Name: Shortest Path to Get All Keys
Intuition: BFS with state = (position, keys collected as bitmask). Track visited states to avoid revisiting.
BFS on bus routes (not stops). Build graph of routes sharing stops. Count route changes from source to target.
BFS from beginWord. Generate all one-char-different words. Check if in wordList. Track level for length.
Multi-source BFS from all gates. Spread outward updating distances. Empty rooms get minimum distance to any gate.
Trie + DFS backtracking. Build trie from words. DFS from each cell matching trie path. Prune visited branches.
Adjacency matrix. DFS/BFS from each unvisited city. Count connected components. Same as number of friend circles.
DFS from border 'O's to mark safe cells. Then flip remaining 'O's to 'X'. Restore marked cells to 'O'.
DFS to find and mark first island. BFS from first island's cells to reach second island. Count BFS levels.
Two-coloring with DFS/BFS. Assign alternating colors to neighbors. If conflict (same color neighbors), not bipartite.
Two pointers: swap first and last, recursively reverse middle portion. Base: pointers cross.
Binary exponentiation: x^n = (x^(n/2))^2. Handle negative n by computing 1/x^(-n). O(log n) time.
XOR all numbers. Pairs cancel out (a^a=0). Single number remains. a^0=a and a^a=0 properties.
dp[i] = dp[i >> 1] + (i & 1). Number of 1s = 1s in i/2 plus last bit. Or dp[i] = dp[i & (i-1)] + 1.
